Ms. Weaver, 34, is keeping her name. She is the author of ''Unzipped'' (Doubleday, 1999), a book about dating and relationships. She graduated from Brown University and received a master's degree in creative writing from New York University. Her mother, Dianne Weaver, lives in San Francisco and is a principal in Town & Company-Morgan Lane, a real estate company there. Her father, David Weaver, who also lives in San Francisco, is a lawyer.

Mr. Frankel, 37, is an associate at Howard, Rice, Nemerovski, Canady, Falk & Rabkin, a San Francisco law firm specializing in intellectual property. He is a summa cum laude graduate of Harvard University and received a Master of Philosophy degree from Cambridge University, where he was a National Science Foundation fellow in the history and philosophy of science, and also a law degree from Yale Law School.
His parents, Louise and James B. Frankel, live in San Francisco. His father retired from Cooper, White & Cooper, a law firm there, to which he was of counsel.

It is not often that a date begins with a request for a nondisclosure statement, even if made in jest. But in this case, a lawyer was going out with a former sex and dating columnist. (She wrote a column on sex and dating for Salon, an online magazine, from 1996 to 1998.)
Ms. Weaver's mother's best friend, Susan McBride, was selling Mr. Frankel a house in late 1998, and thought he and Ms. Weaver might be a good match.

But Ms. Weaver was a little taken aback when told of Mr. Frankel's profession. ''My mother's friend said: 'No, he is a good lawyer. Art law. He's not running after handicapped kids looking for money.' ''
Mr. Frankel, for his part, was intrigued, and cautious. ''I didn't want to wind up fodder for one of her columns,'' he explained.

They played telephone tag for two weeks trying to fit a dinner into their schedules. Finally, Mr. Frankel suggested a date to which Ms. Weaver agreed. Then he said he was only 80 percent sure that he could make it.
''Why don't you call me when you are 100 percent sure,'' Ms. Weaver said she told him.

She then e-mailed a message to a close friend, in which she referred to Mr. Frankel as ''Mr. 80 Percent.'' A few phone attempts later, Ms. Weaver left a message on Mr. Frankel's answering machine suggesting that they just aim for coffee.
''I felt I had been demoted,'' Mr. Frankel said. He quickly called to make a firm dinner arrangement.

Their meeting, at a Thai restaurant on a rainy January evening in 1999, went well. They impressed each other favorably in the charm and wit departments. And Ms. Weaver assured Mr. Frankel that he would not need a nondisclosure statement.
''When I got home, I e-mailed the same friend,'' she recalled. ''I said I didn't know if there was a love connection, but I could talk to him for the rest of my life.''
